speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Chapter Seven: The Art of Description. Writing a great voice description is like sculpting with words. The more specific and evocative you are, the more unique and repeatable your character will be.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Start with the two most anchoring attributes: age and gender. 'A young adult female' or 'an elderly man' immediately give the model a strong foundation to build on.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Next, add texture and pitch. Words like 'raspy', 'breathy', 'gravelly', 'smooth', 'nasal', 'husky', 'deep', or 'high-pitched' are all highly effective. The model has a strong understanding of vocal texture language.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Then, if relevant, add an accent. The model understands many regional accents: British Received Pronunciation, Southern American, Scottish, thick Russian, standard American, and many others. Be specific — 'a slight Scottish lilt' behaves differently from 'a thick Glaswegian accent'.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Here is an example of a complete, professional narrator description: 'A middle-aged woman, mid-forties, smooth and clear voice, standard American accent, warm and reassuring.' That will reliably produce a clean, versatile narrator.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: And here is a fantastical example: 'An ancient, ageless entity with an impossibly deep, distorted, resonant voice, with a slight reverb quality, neither male nor female.' Push the boundaries — the model can handle surreal descriptions too.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The Help Guide contains a full set of Voice Design Character Presets — ready-made descriptions paired with style instructions, covering characters like the Cowboy Narrator, the Ancient Witch, the Cyber Droid, and more. They are an excellent starting point.
